[[File:Imam Ali and the Jinn.jpg|thumb|''[[Imam Ali]] Conquers Jinn'', unknown artist, Ahsan-ol-Kobar (1568) [[Golestan Palace]]|upright=1.35]]{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}}

'''Jinn''' ({{lang-ar|الجن}}, ''{{transl|ar|ALA|al-jinn}}''), also [[Romanization of Arabic|Romanized]] as '''djinn''' or [[Anglicization|Anglicized]] as '''genies''' (with the more broad meaning of [[spirit]]s or [[demon]]s, depending on source)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/jinn|title=jinn – Definition of jinn in English by Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries – English}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 22 (German)</ref> are [[supernatural]] creatures in early pre-Islamic  [[Arabian mythology|Arabian]] and later [[Islamic mythology]] and [[Islamic theology|theology]]. Jinn are not a strictly Islamic concept, rather various [[pagan]] deities integrated into Islam, by turning them to spirits.<ref>Tobias Nünlist Dämonenglaube im Islam Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 2 (German)</ref> Since jinn are not inevitably evil (nor good), Islam was able to adapt spirits from other religions during its expansion. 

Besides the jinn, Islam aknowldges the existence of demons (''Shayāṭīn''). The lines between demons and jinn are blurred, since malevolent jinn are also called ''shayāṭīn''.<ref>Robert Lebling (30 July 2010). Legends of the Fire Spirits: Jinn and Genies from Arabia to Zanzibar. I.B.Tauris. p. 87. {{ISBN|978-0-85773-063-3}}</ref><ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 3 (German)</ref> However both Islam and Western scholarship, distinguishes between angels, jinn and demons (''shayāṭīn'') as three different types of spiritual entities in Islamic traditions.<ref>Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the Jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 21 </ref><ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG'', 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 47 (German)</ref>

In an Islamic context, the term ''jinn'' is used for both a collective designation for any supernatural creature and also to refer to a specific type of supernatural creature.<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 67 (German)</ref>

==Etymology==
''Jinn'' is an [[Arabic language|Arabic]] [[collective number|collective noun]] deriving from the [[Semitic root]] {{sc|jnn}} ({{lang-ar|جَنّ / جُنّ}}, ''jann''), whose primary meaning is "to hide" or "to conceal". Some authors interpret the word to mean, literally, "beings that are concealed from the senses".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tyndalearchive.com/tabs/lane/ |title=An Arabic-English Lexicon |author=Edward William Lane |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150408021742/http://www.tyndalearchive.com/tabs/lane/ |archivedate= 8 April 2015 |df= }}. p. 462.</ref> [[Cognate]]s include the [[Arabic language|Arabic]] ''{{transl|ar|ALA|majnūn}}'' ("possessed", or generally "insane"), ''{{transl|ar|ALA|jannah}}'' ("garden", also “heaven”), and ''{{transl|ar|ALA|janīn}}'' ("embryo").<ref>{{cite book |title=[[Dictionary of Modern Written Arabic]] |last=Wehr |first=Hans |authorlink=Hans Wehr |year=1994 |edition=4 |publisher=Spoken Language Services |location=Urbana, Illinois |isbn=978-0-87950-003-0 |page=164}}</ref> ''Jinn'' is properly treated as a plural, with the singular being ''jinnī''.

The origin of the word Jinn remains uncertain.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Some scholars relate the Arabic term jinn to the Latin genius, as a result of syncretism during the reign of the Roman empire under [[Tiberius]] Augustus,<ref>Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the Jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 38</ref> but this derivation is also disputed.<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 25 (German)</ref> Another suggestion holds that jinn may be derived from [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] "ginnaya" ({{lang-syc|ܓܢܬܐ}}) with the meaning of "[[tutelary deity]]",<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 24 (German)</ref> or also "garden". Others claim a [[Persian language|Persian]] origin of the word, in the form of the Avestic "Jaini", a wicked (female) spirit.  Jaini were among various creatures in the possibly even pre-Zoroastrian mythology of peoples of Iran.<ref>Tisdall, W. St. Clair. The Original Sources of the Qur'an, Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge, London, 1905</ref><ref>The Religion of the Crescent or Islam: Its Strength, Its Weakness, Its Origin, Its Influence, William St. Clair Tisdall, 1895</ref>

The [[Anglicization|Anglicized]] form ''genie'' is a borrowing of the French ''{{lang|fr|génie}}'', from the [[Latin]] ''[[genius (mythology)|genius]]'', a guardian spirit of people and places in [[ancient Roman religion|Roman religion]]. It first appeared<ref name=oed>''Oxford English Dictionary'', 3rd ed. "genie, ''n''." Oxford University Press (Oxford), 2014.</ref> in 18th-century translations of the ''[[The Book of One Thousand and One Nights|Thousand and One Nights]]'' from the French,<ref>{{citation |title=Arabian Nights' entertainments |year=1706 |volume=Vol. I |p=14 }}.</ref> where it had been used owing to its rough similarity in sound and sense.

== Pre-Islamic Arabia ==
{{see also|Religion in pre-Islamic Arabia}}
Jinn were worshipped by many Arabs during the [[Pre-Islamic Arabia|Pre-Islamic period]],<ref name="ReferenceB">Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the Jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 34</ref> but, unlike gods, jinn were not regarded as [[Immortality|immortal]]. In ancient Arabia, the term ''jinn'' also applied to all kinds of supernatural entities among various religions and cults; thus, [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrian]], Christian, and [[Judaism|Jewish]] angels and demons were also called "jinn".<ref name="ReferenceB" />

The exact origins of belief in jinn are not entirely clear.<ref name="Lebling1–10">{{cite book |last1=Lebling |first1=Robert |title=Legends of the Fire Spirits: Jinn and Genies from Arabia to Zanzibar |date=2010 |publisher=I. B. Tauris |location=New York City, New York and London, England |isbn=978-0-85773-063-3 |pages=1–10 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=qKL3AgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=ancient+Mesopotamian+genii+and+Islamic+jinn#v=onepage&q=Mesopotamia&f=false |ref=harv}}</ref> Some scholars of the Middle East hold that they originated as malevolent spirits residing in deserts and unclean places, who often took the forms of animals;<ref name="Lebling1–10" /> others hold that they were originally pagan nature deities who gradually became marginalized as other deities took greater importance.<ref name="Lebling1–10" /> According to common Arabian belief, [[Fortune-telling|soothsayer]]s, pre-Islamic philosophers, and poets were inspired by the jinn.<ref name="ReferenceB" /><ref name="Lebling1–10" /> However, jinn were also feared and thought to be responsible for causing various diseases and mental illnesses.<ref>Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the Jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 122</ref><ref name="Lebling1–10" /> [[Julius Wellhausen]] observed that such spirits were thought to inhabit desolate, dingy, and dark places and that they were feared.<ref name="Zeitlin59">{{cite book|author=Irving M. Zeitlin|title=The Historical Muhammad|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v_seJ21M0UoC&pg=PT59|date=19 March 2007|publisher=Polity|isbn=978-0-7456-3999-4|pages=59–60}}</ref> One had to protect oneself from them, but they were not the objects of a true cult.<ref name="Zeitlin59" />

==Islamic theology==
{{see also|Islamic mythology}}
In the Islamic sense, ''jinn'' is used in two different ways:

* As the opposite of ''al-Ins'' (something in shape) referring to any object that cannot be detected by human sensory organs, including [[angels in Islam|Angels]], [[Shaitan|Demon]]s and the interior of human beings. Thus every Demon and every Angel is also a jinn, but not every Jinn is an Angel or a Demon.<ref>Scott B. Noegel, Brannon M. Wheeler ''The A to Z of Prophets in Islam and Judaism'' Scarecrow Press 2010 {{ISBN|978-1-461-71895-6}} page 170</ref><ref>University of Michigan ''Muhammad Asad: Europe's Gift to Islam, Band 1'' Truth Society 2006 {{ISBN|978-9-693-51852-8}} page 387</ref><ref>Richard Gauvain ''Salafi Ritual Purity: In the Presence of God'' Routledge 2013 {{ISBN|978-0-710-31356-0}} page 302</ref>
*An invisible entity, created by God out of a "mixture of fire" or "smokeless fire", who roamed the earth before Adam. These entities are believed to resemble humans with regard to the need of eating and drinking, procreation and dying, being subject to judgment they will either be condemned to heaven or hell according to their deeds.<ref>Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the Jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 18</ref> But they were much faster and stronger than humans.<ref name="ReferenceC">John Andrew Morrow ''Islamic Images and Ideas: Essays on Sacred Symbolism'' McFarland, 27 November 2013 {{ISBN|978-1-476-61288-1}} page 73</ref> Jinn are also related to heavenly beings, a sub-category of angels or a tribe of angelic beings, who is able to sin and created from fire, unlike their light-created counterpart.<ref>Stephen J. Vicchio ''Biblical Figures in the Islamic Faith'' Wipf and Stock Publishers 2008 {{ISBN|978-1-556-35304-8}} page 183</ref> However these jinn must be distinguished, from the Pre-Adamite jinn-race, who share many characteristics with human, instead of angels.

In Islamic tradition, [[Muhammad in Islam|Muhammad]] was sent as a [[prophets of Islam|prophet]] to both human and jinn communities, and that prophets and messengers were sent to both communities.<ref>{{Quran-usc|51|56|end=56|style=nosup}}</ref><ref>Muḥammad ibn Ayyūb al-Ṭabarī, ''Tuḥfat al-gharā’ib'', I, p. 68; Abū al-Futūḥ Rāzī, ''Tafsīr-e rawḥ al-jenān va rūḥ al-janān'', pp. 193, 341</ref> Traditionally [[Al-Jinn|Surah 72]] is held to tell about the revelation to Jinn and several stories mention one of Muhammad's followers accompanied him, witnessing the revelation to the Jinn.<ref>Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the Jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 64</ref>

Another Islamic prophet, who is related to interactions with Jinn, is [[Solomon in Islam|Solomon]]. In Quran, he is said to be a king in [[History of ancient Israel and Judah|ancient Israel]] and was gifted by [[God in Islam|God]] to talk to animals and Jinn. God granted him authority over the rebellious Jinn or ''[[marid]]'', thus Solomon forced them to build the [[Solomon's Temple|First Temple]]. Beliefs regarding Solomon and his power over the Jinn were later extended in folklore and folktales.

Related to common traditions, the angels were created on Wednesday, the Jinn on Thursday and humans on Friday, but not the very next day, rather more than 1000 years later.<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 43 (German)</ref> The community of the Jinn race were like these of humans, but then corruption and injustice among them increased and all warnings sent by God were ignored. Consequently, God sent his angels to battle the infidel Jinn. Just a few survived, and were ousted to far islands or to the [[Mount Qaf|mountains]]. With the revelation of Islam, the Jinn were given a new chance to access salvation.<ref>Patrick Hughes, ''Thomas Patrick Hughes Dictionary of Islam'' Asian Educational Services 1995 page 134 {{ISBN|978-8-120-60672-2}}</ref><ref>Gabriel Said Reynolds ''The Qur'an and Its Biblical Subtext'' Routledge 2010 {{ISBN|978-1-135-15020-4}} page 41</ref><ref>Tubanur Yesilhark Ozkan ''A Muslim Response to Evil: Said Nursi on the Theodicy'' Routledge 2016 {{ISBN|978-1-317-18754-7}} page 141</ref> But because of their anciennity, the jinn would attribute themselves to a superiority over humans and envy the them for their place and rank on earth.<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam Walter'' de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 43 (German)</ref>

==Development of Islamic Jinn belief==
[[File:Kitab al-Bulhan --- devils talking.jpg|thumb|right=0.4|The black king of the djinns, Al-Malik al-Aswad, from the late 14th century [[Book of Wonders]]]]

===In the beginning of Islam===
In early Islamic development, the status of jinn were reduced from that of deities<ref>Christopher R. Fee, Jeffrey B. Webb ''American Myths, Legends, and Tall Tales: An Encyclopedia of American Folklore [3 volumes]: An Encyclopedia of American Folklore (3 Volumes)'' ABC-CLIO 2016 {{ISBN|978-1-610-69568-8}} page 527</ref> to minor spirits. To assert a strict [[monotheism]] and the Islamic concept of [[Tauhid]], all affinities between the jinn and God were denied, thus jinn were placed parallel to humans, also subject to God's judgment and able to attain [[Paradise]] or [[Hell]]. However, even though their status as tutelary deities was reduced, they were not consequently regarded as demons.<ref>Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the Jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 52</ref> In later revelations, the concept of demons and angels distinct from the pagan jinn were made.<ref>Jacques Waardenburg Islam: Historical, Social, and Political Perspectives Walter de Gruyter 2008 {{ISBN|978-3-110-20094-2}} page 40</ref> T. Fahd stated, the jinn were related to the pagan belief, while the demons and angels were borrowed from [[Abrahamic religions|monotheistic concepts]] of angels and demons. In later revelations the demons and the jinn seems to be used interchangeably, here placing the jinn with the [[Devil#Islam|devil]], against the angels and [[Muhammad]].

===Jinn belief in the later centuries===
[[File:Iranischer Meister 001.jpg|thumb|left|[[Zulqarnayn]] with the help of some jinn, building the Iron Wall to keep the barbarian [[Gog and Magog]] from civilized peoples (16th century [[Persian miniature]])]]
When Islam spread outside of Arabia, belief in the jinn was assimilated with local belief about [[spirit]]s and [[deity|deities]] from Iran, Africa, Turkey and India.<ref>Juan Eduardo Campo Encyclopedia of Islam Infobase Publishing 2009 {{ISBN|978-1-438-12696-8}} page 402</ref> Persians, for example, identified the jinn in the Quran with the [[Daeva]] from [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrian]] lore.<ref>Patrick Hughes, Thomas Patrick Hughes ''Dictionary of Islam'' Asian Educational Services 1995 {{ISBN|978-8-120-60672-2}} page 134</ref> Developed from various traditions and local folklore, but not mentioned in canonical Islamic scriptures, jinn were thought to be able to possess humans; [[Morocco]] especially has many possession traditions, including [[Exorcism in Islam|exorcism rituals]].<ref>Joseph P. Laycock ''Spirit Possession around the World: Possession, Communion, and Demon Expulsion across Cultures: Possession, Communion, and Demon Expulsion across Cultures'' ABC-CLIO 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-610-69590-9}} page 243</ref> In [[Sindh]] the concept of the Jinni was introduced during the [[Abbasid Caliphate|Abbasid Era]] and has become a common part of local folklore, also including stories of both male jinn called "''jinn''" and female jinn called "''Jiniri''". Folk stories of female jinn include stories such as the ''Jejhal Jiniri''. Although, due to the cultural influence, the concept of jinn may vary, all share some common features. The jinn are believed to live in societies resembling these of humans, practicing religion (including Islam, Christianity and Judaism), having emotions, needing to eat and drink, and can procreate and raise families. Additionally, they fear iron, generally appear in desolate or abandoned places, and are stronger and faster than humans.<ref name="Hughes, Thomas Patrick 1885. p.136">Hughes, Thomas Patrick. ''Dictionary of Islam''. 1885. "Genii" p.136</ref> Generally, jinn are thought to eat bones and prefer rotten flesh over fresh flesh.<ref>Abu’l-Fotūḥ, XVII, pp. 280–281</ref>

The composition and existence of jinn is the subject of various debates during the [[Middle Age]]s. According to [[Ashari]], the existence of jinn can not be proven, because arguments concerning the existence of jinn are beyond human comprehension. Adepts of [[Ashʿari theology]] explained jinn are invisible to humans, because they lack the appropriate sense organs to envision them.<ref>Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 22</ref> Critics argued, if jinn exist, their bodies must either be ethereal or made of solid material; if they were composed of the former, they would not able to do hard work, like carrying heavy stones. If they were composed of the latter, they would be visible to any human with functional eyes.<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p.33 (German)</ref> Critics therefore refused to believe in a literal reading on jinn in Islamic sacred texts, preferring to view them as "unruly men".<ref>Hughes, Thomas Patrick. ''Dictionary of Islam''. 1885. "Genii" p.134</ref> On the other hand, advocates of belief in jinn assert that God's creation can exceed the human mind; thus, jinn are beyond human understanding. Since they are mentioned in Islamic texts, scholars such as [[Ibn Taimiyya]] and [[Ibn Hazm]] prohibit the denial of jinn. They also refer to spirits and demons among the Christians, Zoroastrians and Jews to "prove" their existence.<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p.33 (German)</ref> Ibn Taymiyya believed the jinn to be generally "ignorant, untruthful, oppressive and treacherous". He held that the jinn account for much of the "magic" that is perceived by humans, cooperating with magicians to lift items in the air, delivering hidden truths to fortune tellers, and mimicking the voices of deceased humans during seances.<ref name="taym">[[Ibn Taymiyyah]], ''al-Furqān bayna awliyā’ al-Raḥmān wa-awliyā’ al-Shayṭān'' ("Essay on the Jinn"), translated by Abu Ameenah Bilal Phillips</ref>

Other critics, such as [[Jahiz]] and [[Mas'udi]], stated that sightings of jinn are due to psychological causes. According to Mas'udi, the jinn as described by traditional scholars, are not [[A priori and a posteriori|''a priori'']] false, but improbable. Jahiz states in his work [[Kitab al-Hayawan]] that loneliness induces humans to mind-games and wishful thinking, causing ''waswās'' (whisperings in the mind, traditionally thought to be caused by [[Satan]]). If he is afraid, he may see things that are not real. These alleged appearances are told to other generations in bedtime stories and poems, and with children of the next generation growing up with such stories, when they are afraid or lonely, they remember these stories, encouraging their imaginations and causing another alleged sighting of jinn.<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p.37 (German)</ref>

Later [[Sufism|Sufi traditions]] related the meaning of jinn back to its origin "something that is concealed from sights", thus they were related to the hidden realm, including angels from the heavenly realm and the jinn from a sublunary realm. [[Ibn Arabi]] stated: "Only this much is different: The spirits of the jinn are lower spirits, while the spirits of angels are heavenly spirits".<ref>"http://www.ibnarabisociety.org/articles/futuhat_ch009.html</ref> The jinn share, due to their [[Barzakh|intermediary abode]] both angelic and human traits. According to some Sufi teachings, a jinn is like an "empty cup", composed of its own ego and intention, and a reflection of its observer.<ref>H.J. Witteveen ''The Heart of Sufism: Essential Writings of Hazrat Inayat Khan'' Shambhala Publications 1999 {{ISBN|978-0-834-82874-2}}</ref> Because jinn are closer to the material realm, it would be easier for human to contact a jinn, than an angel.<ref>Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the Jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 50</ref>

==== In folk literature ====
[[File:ManuscriptAbbasid.jpg|thumb|right|Abbasid manuscript of the ''[[One Thousand and One Nights]]'']]
Jinn can be found in the ''[[One Thousand and One Nights]]'' story of "[[The Fisherman and the Jinni]]";<ref name="classiclit.about.com">[http://classiclit.about.com/library/bl-etexts/arabian/bl-arabian-jinni.htm The fisherman and the Jinni] at About.com Classic Literature</ref> more than three different types of jinn are described in the story of ''Ma‘ruf the Cobbler'';<ref>[http://www.idriesshahfoundation.org/books/tales-of-the-dervishes/ Idries Shah – Tales of the Dervishes] at ISF website</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wollamshram.ca/1001/Vol_10/tale169.htm|title=MA’ARUF THE COBBLER AND HIS WIFE}}</ref> two jinn help young [[Aladdin]] in the story of ''Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp'';<ref>[http://classiclit.about.com/library/bl-etexts/arabian/bl-arabian-alladin.htm The Arabian Nights – ALADDIN; OR, THE WONDERFUL LAMP] at About.com Classic Literature</ref> as Ḥasan Badr al-Dīn weeps over the grave of his father until sleep overcomes him, and he is awoken by a large group of sympathetic jinn in the ''Tale of ‘Alī Nūr al-Dīn and his son Badr ad-Dīn Ḥasan''.<ref>[http://classiclit.about.com/library/bl-etexts/arabian/bl-arabian-nuraldin.htm The Arabian Nights – TALE OF NUR AL-DIN ALI AND HIS SON BADR AL-DIN HASAN] at About.com Classic Literature</ref> In some stories, jinn are credited with the ability of [[teleportation|instantaneous travel]] (from China to Morocco in a single instant); in others, they need to fly from one place to another, though quite fast (from Baghdad to Cairo in a few hours).

===Modern era===
Affirmation on the existence of Jinn as sapient creatures living along with humans is still widespread in the Middle Eastern world and mental illnesses are often attributed to jinn possession.<ref>G. Hussein Rassool ''Islamic Counselling: An Introduction to theory and practice'' Routledge, 16.07.2015 {{ISBN|978-1-31744-125-0}} p. 58</ref>

However some [[modernism|modernist commentators]], on the basis of the word's meaning, reinterpretated references to jinn as microorganisms such as [[bacteria]] and [[virus]]es or undetectable uncivilized persons.<ref>Simon Ross Valentine ''Islam and the Ahmadiyya Jama'at: History, Belief, Practice'' Hurst Publishers 2008 {{ISBN|978-1-850-65916-7}} page 143</ref><ref>U. A. B. Razia Akter Banu ''Islam in Bangladesh'' BRILL 1992 {{ISBN|978-9-004-09497-0}} page 57</ref> Others try to [[Pseudoscience|reconcile the traditional perspective on jinn, with modern sciences]]. [[Fethullah Gülen]], leader of [[Gülen movement|Hizmet movement]], had put forward the idea, that jinn may be the cause of [[schizophrenia]] and [[cancer]] and that the Quranic references to jinn on "smokeless fire" could for that matter mean "energy".<ref>John Grant ''Denying Science: Conspiracy Theories, Media Distortions, and the War Against Reality'' Prometheus Books {{ISBN|978-1-616-14400-5}}</ref> Others again refuse connections between illness and jinn, but still believe in their existence, due to their occurrences in the Quran.<ref>Alireza Doostdar ''The Iranian Metaphysicals: Explorations in Science, Islam, and the Uncanny'' {{ISBN|978-1-400-88978-5}} Princeton University Press 2018 page 54</ref> 

Modern [[Salafi]] tenets of Islam, refuse reinterpretations of jinn and adhere to [[Bi-la kaifa|literalism]], arguing the threat of jinn and their ability to possess humans, could be proven by ''[[Quran and Sunnah]]''.<ref>https://islamqa.info/en/1819</ref> Jinn are taken as serious danger by adherents of Salafism. [[Saudi Arabia]], following the [[Wahhabism]] strant of Salafism, impose [[Capital punishment in Saudi Arabia|death penalty]] for dealing with jinn to prevent [[Magic (supernatural)|sorcery]] and [[witchcraft]].<ref>https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2015/08/the-death-penalty-in-saudi-arabia-facts-and-figures/</ref><ref>https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2013/08/saudi-arabias-war-on-witchcraft/278701/</ref> Further, there is no distinction made between demons and indifferent spirits from other cultures, as Salafi scholars [[Umar Sulaiman Al-Ashqar]] stated,<ref>https://islamqa.info/en/20666</ref> that demons are actually simply ''unbelieving jinn''.

==== Research ====
[[File:Jinn_causing_toothaches.jpg|thumb|right|18th century Ottoman Manuscript depicting Jinn causing toothaches]]
[[Sleep paralysis]] is conceptualized as a "Jinn attack" by many sleep paralysis sufferers in Egypt as discovered by [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]] neuroscientist Baland Jalal.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Jalal|first=Baland|last2=Simons-Rudolph|first2=Joseph|last3=Jalal|first3=Bamo|last4=Hinton|first4=Devon E.|date=1 October 2013|title=Explanations of sleep paralysis among Egyptian college students and the general population in Egypt and Denmark|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/1363461513503378|journal=Transcultural Psychiatry|volume=51|issue=2|pages=158–175|doi=10.1177/1363461513503378}}</ref> A scientific study found that as many as 48 percent of those who experience sleep paralysis in Egypt believe it to be an assault by the Jinn.<ref name=":0" /> Almost all of these sleep paralysis sufferers (95%) would recite verses from the [[Quran]] during sleep paralysis to prevent future "Jinn attacks". In addition, some (9%) would increase their daily Islamic prayer ([[salah]]) to get rid of these attacks by Jinn.<ref name=":0" /> Sleep paralysis is generally associated with great fear in Egypt, especially if believed to be supernatural in origin.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jalal|first=Baland|last2=Hinton|first2=Devon E.|date=1 September 2013|title=Rates and Characteristics of Sleep Paralysis in the General Population of Denmark and Egypt|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11013-013-9327-x|journal=Culture, Medicine, and Psychiatry|volume=37|issue=3|pages=534–548|doi=10.1007/s11013-013-9327-x|issn=0165-005X}}</ref>

==Supernaturality==
The supernaturality of Jinn does not mean they are transcendent to nature, but that they appear so in relation to human's perception of nature, due to their invisibility. They are "natural" in the [[Ancient philosophy|classical philosopical]] sense by consisting of an element, undergoing change and being bound in time and space.<ref>Benjamin W. McCraw, Robert Arp ''Philosophical Approaches to the Devil'' Routledge 2015 {{ISBN|9781317392217}}</ref> Thus they are not purely spiritual, but also physical in nature, being able to interact in a tactile manner with people and objects, and also subject to bodily desires like eating and sleeping. Unlike the Jinn in Islamic belief and folklore, Jinn in Middle Eastern folktales are often depicted as monstrous or magical creatures, and unlike the former, generally considered to be fictional.<ref name="Robert Lebling">Robert Lebling ''Legends of the Fire Spirits: Jinn and Genies from Arabia to Zanzibar'' I.B.Tauris 2010 {{ISBN|978-0-857-73063-3}}</ref>

== Depictions ==
The appearance of jinn can be divided into three major categories<ref>Tobias Nünlist Dämonenglaube im Islam Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 113 (German)</ref>:

=== Zoomorphic manifestation ===
Jinn are assumed to be able to appear in shape of various animals such as skorpions, cats, [[owl]]s and [[onagers]]. The dog is also often related to jinn, especially black dogs. However piebald dogs are rahter identified with [[Hinn (mythology)|hinn]]. Associations between dogs and jinn prevailed in Arabic-literature, but lost its meaning in Persian scriptures.<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 134 (German)</ref> Serpents are the animals most associated with jinn. Islamic traditions knows many narratitions concerning a serpent who was actually a jinni.<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 116 (German)</ref> However (except for the '''udhrut'' from [[Fortune-telling|Yemeni]] folklore) the jinn can not appear in form of wolves. The wolf is thought of as the [[Predation|natural predator]] of the jinn, who contrasts the jinn by his noble character and disables them to vanish.<ref>name="ReferenceA">Robert Lebling Legends of the Fire Spirits: Jinn and Genies from Arabia to Zanzibar Legends of the Fire Spirits: Jinn and Genies from Arabia to Zanzibar 2010 {{ISBN|978-0-857-73063-3}} page 98</ref><ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 43 (German)</ref>

=== Jinn in form of storms and shadows ===
The jinn are also related to the wind. They may appear in mists or sandstorms.<ref name="Hughes, Thomas Patrick 1885. p.136"/> [[Zubayr ibn al-Awam]], who is held to have accompanied Muhammad during his lecture to the jinn, is said to view the jinn as shadowy ghosts with no individual structure.<ref>Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the Jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 64</ref> According to a narration [[Ghazali]] asked [[Ṭabasī]], famous for jinn-incantations, to reveal the jinn to him. Accordingly Tabasi showed him the jinn, seeing them like they were "a shadow on the wall". After Ghazali requested to speak to them, Ṭabasī stated, that for now he could not see more.<ref>Travis Zadeh  ''Commanding Demons and Jinn: The Sorcerer in Early Islamic Thought'' p.145</ref> Although sandstorms are believed to be caused by jinn, others, such as [[Abu Yahya Zakariya' ibn Muhammad al-Qazwini]] and Ghazali attribute them to natural causes.<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 147 (German)</ref> Otherwise sandstorms are thought to be caused by a battle between different groups of jinn.

=== Anthropomorphic manifestation ===
A common characteristic of the jinn is their lack of individuality, but they may gain individuality by materializing in human forms <ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 153 (German)</ref> such as [[Asmodeus|Sakhr]] and severel jinn known from magical writings. But also in their anthropomorphed shape, they stay partly animalic and are not fully human. Therefore, individual jinn are commonly depicted as monstrous and anthropomorphized creatures with body parts from different animals or human with animalic traits.<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 164 (German)</ref> Commonly associated with jinn in humanform are the [[Sila (mythology)|Si'lah]] and the [[Ghoul]]. However, they stay partly animalic, their bodies are depicted as fashioned out of two or more different species.<ref>Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the Jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 164</ref> Some of them may have the hands of cats, the head of birds or wings rise from their shoulders.<ref>Tobias Nünlist ''Dämonenglaube im Islam'' Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG, 2015 {{ISBN|978-3-110-33168-4}} p. 160 (German)</ref>

==In witchcraft and magical literature==
[[File:Kitab al-Bulhan --- demons.jpg|thumb|right=1.4|Zawba'a or Zoba'ah, the demon king of Friday]]
[[Witchcraft]] (''sihr'') is often associated with Jinn and [[Ifrit|Afarit]]<ref>Ian Richard Netton ''Encyclopaedia of Islam'' Routledge 2013 {{ISBN|978-1-135-17960-1}} page 377</ref> around the Middle East. Therefore, a sorcerer may summon a Jinn and force him to perform orders. Summoned Jinn may be sent to the chosen victim to cause demonic possession. Such summonings were done by invocation,<ref>name="Robert Lebling">Robert Lebling ''Legends of the Fire Spirits: Jinn and Genies from Arabia to Zanzibar'' I.B.Tauris 2010 {{ISBN|978-0-857-73063-3}} page 153</ref> by aid of talismans or by satisfying the Jinn, thus to make a contract.<ref>Gerda Sengers ''Women and Demons: Cultic Healing in Islamic Egypt'' BRILL 2003 {{ISBN|978-9-004-12771-5}} page 31</ref> Jinn are also regarded as assistants of [[Fortune-telling|soothsayer]]s. Soothsayers reveal information from the past and present; the Jinn can be a source of this information because their lifespans exceed those of humans.<ref name="ReferenceC"/>

[[Ibn al-Nadim]], in his ''Kitāb al-Fihrist'', describes a book that lists 70 Jinn led by Fuqtus, including several Jinn appointed over each day of the week.<ref name="Dodge">Bayard Dodge, ed. and trans. ''The Fihrist of al-Nadim: A Tenth-Century Survey of Muslim Culture.'' New York: Columbia University Press, 1970. pp. 727–8.</ref><ref name="Lebling">Robert Lebling. ''Legends of the Fire Spirits: Jinn and Genies from Arabia to Zanzibar.'' I.B. Taurus, 2010. p.38</ref> [[Bayard Dodge]], who translated al-Fihrist into English, notes that most of these names appear in the [[Testament of Solomon]].<ref name="Dodge" /> A collection of late fourteenth- or early fifteenth-century magico-medical manuscripts from [[Ocaña, Spain]] describes a different set of 72 Jinn (termed "Tayaliq") again under Fuqtus (here named "Fayqayțūš" or Fiqitush), blaming them for various ailments.<ref>Celia del Moral. ''Magia y Superstitión en los Manuscritos de Ocaña (Toledo). Siglos XIV-XV.'' Proceedings of the 20th Congress of the Union Européenne des Arabisants et Islamisants, Part Two; A. Fodor, ed.  Budapest, 10–17 September 2000. pp.109–121</ref><ref>Joaquina Albarracin Navarro & Juan Martinez Ruiz. ''Medicina, Farmacopea y Magia en el "Misceláneo de Salomón"''.  Universidad de Granada, 1987. p.38 et passim</ref> According to these manuscripts, each Jinni was brought before King Solomon and ordered to divulge their "corruption" and "residence" while the Jinn King Fiqitush gave Solomon a recipe for curing the ailments associated with each Jinni as they confessed their transgressions.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Book of Deadly Names|last = Shadrach|first = Nineveh|publisher = Ishtar Publishing|year = 2007|isbn = 978-0978388300|location = |pages = }}</ref>

A disseminated treatise on the [[occult]], written by [[Abū al-Faḍl Muhammad al Ṭabasī|al-Ṭabasī]], called [[al-Shāmil fī al-baḥr al-kāmil|Shāmil]], deals with subjugating demons and jinn by incantations, charms and the combination of written and recited formulae and to obtain supernatural powers through their aid. Al-Ṭabasī distinguished between licit and illicit magic, the later founded on disbelief, while the first on purity.<ref>Travis Zadeh ''Commanding Demons and Jinn: The Sorcerer in Early Islamic Thought'' Wiesbaden: Harrassowitz Verlag, 2014  p-143-145</ref> 

Seven kings of the Jinn are traditionally associated with days of the week.<ref name="Lebling2010">{{cite book|author=Robert Lebling|title=Legends of the Fire Spirits: Jinn and Genies from Arabia to Zanzibar|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qKL3AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT87|date=30 July 2010|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-0-85773-063-3|pages=87}}</ref>
* Sunday: Al-Mudhib (Abu 'Abdallah Sa'id)
* Monday: Murrah al-Abyad Abu al-Harith (Abu al-Nur)
* Tuesday: Abu Mihriz (or Abu Ya'qub) Al-Ahmar
* Wednesday: Barqan Abu al-'Adja'yb
* Thursday: Shamhurish (al-Tayyar)
* Friday: Abu Hasan Zoba'ah (al-Abyad)
* Saturday: Abu Nuh Maimun

During the [[Rwandan genocide]], both [[Hutu]]s and [[Tutsi]]s avoided searching local [[Islam in Rwanda|Rwandan Muslim]] neighborhoods because they widely believed the myth that local [[Muslim]]s and mosques were protected by the power of Islamic magic and the efficacious Jinn.{{citation needed|date=February 2014}} In the Rwandan city of [[Cyangugu]], arsonists ran away instead of destroying the mosque because they feared the wrath of the jinn, whom they believed were guarding the mosque.<ref name = "Kubai">{{cite journal

==Comparative mythology==
===Ancient Mesopotamian religion===
Beliefs in entities similar to the jinn are found throughout pre-Islamic Middle Eastern cultures.<ref name="Lebling1–10"/> The ancient [[Sumer]]ians believed in [[Pazuzu]], a wind demon,<ref name="Lebling1–10"/><ref name="BlackGreen1992">{{cite book|last=Black|first=Jeremy|first2=Anthony|last2=Green|title=Gods, Demons and Symbols of Ancient Mesopotamia: An Illustrated Dictionary|publisher=The British Museum Press|year=1992|isbn=978-0-7141-1705-8|ref=harv}}</ref>{{rp|147–148}} who was shown with "a rather canine face with abnormally bulging eyes, a scaly body, a snake-headed penis, the talons of a bird and usually wings."<ref name="BlackGreen1992"/>{{rp|147}} The ancient Babylonians believed in ''[[utukku]]'', a class of demons which were believed to haunt remote wildernesses, graveyards, mountains, and the sea, all locations where jinn were later thought to reside.<ref name="Lebling1–10"/> The Babylonians also believed in the [[Rabisu]], a [[vampire|vampiric]] demon believed to leap out and attack travelers at unfrequented locations, similar to the post-Islamic ''[[ghoul|ghūl]]'',<ref name="Lebling1–10"/> a specific kind of jinn whose name is etymologically related to that of the Sumerian ''[[gallu|galla]]'', a class of [[Ancient Mesopotamian Underworld|Underworld]] demon.<ref>{{cite book|author=Cramer, Marc|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fdB-AAAAMAAJ&q=ghoul+galla+sumerian&dq=ghoul+galla+sumerian|title= The Devil Within|publisher=W.H. Allen|year=1979|isbn=978-0-491-02366-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://socrates.berkeley.edu/~caforum/volume8/vol8_article3.html |title=Cultural Analysis, Volume 8, 2009: The Mythical Ghoul in Arabic Culture / Ahmed Al-Rawi |publisher=Socrates.berkeley.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>

[[Lamashtu]], also known as Labartu, was a divine demoness said to devour human infants.<ref name="Lebling1–10"/><ref name="BlackGreen1992"/>{{rp|115}} [[Lamassu]], also known as Shedu, were guardian spirits, sometimes with evil propensities.<ref name="Lebling1–10"/><ref name="BlackGreen1992"/>{{rp|115–116}} The [[Assyria]]ns believed in the [[Alû]], sometimes described as a wind demon residing in desolate ruins who would sneak into people's houses at night and steal their sleep.<ref name="Lebling1–10"/> In the ancient Syrian city of [[Palmyra]], entities similar to jinn were known as ''ginnayê'',<ref name="Lebling1–10"/> an [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] name which may be etymologically derived from the name of the ''[[Genius (mythology)|genii]]'' from [[Roman mythology]].<ref name="Lebling1–10"/> Like jinn among modern-day [[Bedouin]], ''ginnayê'' were thought to resemble humans.<ref name="Lebling1–10"/> They protected caravans, cattle, and villages in the desert<ref name="Lebling1–10"/> and [[Tutelary deity|tutelary]] shrines were kept in their honor.<ref name="Lebling1–10"/> They were frequently invoked in pairs.<ref name="Lebling1–10"/>

===Judaism===
[[Shedim]], one of several supernatural creatures in early [[Jewish mythology]], resemble the Islamic concept of Jinn. Both are said to be invisible to human eyes but are subject to bodily desires, like procreating and the need to eat, and both may be malevolent or benevolent. Like the Islamic notion of jinn as Pre-Adamites, Jewish lore also regard shedim as Pre-Adamites, replaced by human beings in some legends.<ref>Carol K. Mack, Dinah Mack A Field Guide to Demons, Vampires, Fallen Angels and Other Subversive Spirits'' Skyhorse Publishing 2013 {{ISBN|978-1-628-72150-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://intothewonder.wordpress.com/2014/03/07/shedim-eldritch-beings-from-jewish-folklore/|title=Shedim: Eldritch Beings from Jewish Folklore|date=7 March 2014}}</ref> Narrations regarding [[Asmodeus]], an antagonist in the Solomon legends, appears both in Islamic lore and in the [[Talmud]] as the king either of the jinn or the shedim.<ref name="Robert Lebling"/>{{rp|120}}

===Buddhism===
Similar to the Islamic idea of spiritual entities converting to one's own religion can be found on [[Buddhism]] lore. Accordingly, Buddha preached among humans and [[Deva (Buddhism)|Deva]]s, spiritual entities who are like humans subject to the cycle of life, that resembles the Islamic notion of Jinn, who are also [[ontologically]] placed among humans in regard of their [[Eschatology|eschatological]] destiny.<ref>Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the Jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 165</ref><ref>Marie Musæus-Higgins ''Poya Days'' Asian Educational Services 1925 {{ISBN|978-8-120-61321-8}} page 14</ref>

===Christianity===
[[Cornelius Van Allen Van Dyck|Van Dyck]]'s Arabic translation of the Old Testament uses the alternative collective plural "jann" (Arab:الجان}; translation:al-jānn) to render the Hebrew word usually translated into English as "familiar spirit" (אוב , [[Strong's Concordance|Strong]] #0178) in several places ([[Leviticus]] 19:31, 20:6, [[1 Samuel]] 28:3,7,9, [[1 Chronicles]] 10:13).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabicbible.com/arabic-bible.html|title=Arabic Bible – Arabic Bible Outreach Ministry|website=''arabicbible.com''}}</ref>

=== Guanche mythology ===
In [[Church of the Guanche People|Guanche mythology]] from [[Tenerife]] in the [[Canary Islands]], there existed the belief in beings that were similar to genies,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.eldia.es/afondo/2013-07-07/1-guanches-perros-llegaron-juntos-Tenerife.htm|title=Los guanches y los perros llegaron juntos a Tenerife|date=7 July 2013}} (Spanish)</ref> such as the ''[[maxios]]'' or ''dioses paredros'' ("attendant gods", domestic and nature spirits) and ''[[tibicena]]s'' (evil genies), as well as the demon ''[[Guayota]]'' (aboriginal god of evil) that, like the Arabic ''[[Devil (Islam)|{{transl|ar|ALA|Iblīs}}]]'', is sometimes identified with a genie.<ref>[http://www.eldia.es/2009-08-23/CRITERIOS/3-Religion-guanche.htm Guanche Religion] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091002215856/http://www.eldia.es/2009-08-23/CRITERIOS/3-Religion-guanche.htm |date= 2 October 2009 }} (Spanish)</ref> The [[Guanches]] were the [[Berbers|Berber]] natives of the Canary Islands before they were colonised and enslaved by the Europeans who claimed the island for themselves.

==In popular culture==
{{main|Genie in popular culture}}

The jinn frequently occurs as a character or plot element in fiction. Two other classes of jinn, the [[ifrit]] and the [[marid]], have been represented in fiction as well.

Genies appear in film in various forms, such as the genie freed by Abu, the eponymous character in the 1940 film ''[[The Thief of Bagdad (1940 film)|Thief of Bagdad]]''.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news |author=Crowther, Bosley |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/49447/The-Thief-of-Bagdad/details |title='The Thief of Bagdad,' a Delightful Fairy Tale, at the Music Hall--'Lady With Red Hair,' at the Palace |accessdate=2 July 2016 |date=6 December 1940 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>

A Jinni makes a short appearance in the novel ''[[American Gods]]'' by [[Neil Gaiman]], originally published in 2001.  ''American Gods'' was also made into a TV series for the Starz television cable television network in 2017. The television adaptation also features a Jinni.

The protagonist of the [[Bartimaeus Sequence]] is a jinni, and the books have an established hierarchy that include other types of spirits: imps, foliots, djinn, afrits, and marids (to use the author's own spelling). In this interpretation, jinn and all other spirits are not physical beings, but are instead from another dimension of chaos called "The Other Place". To exist on Earth at all, magicians must summon sprits and force them to take some kind of form, something so alien that it causes all spirits pain. As a result, magicians must put measures in place to force spirits to do what they want in a form of magical slavery.

In the popular American television series, "[[Supernatural]]", the jinn (alternatively 'djinn' or 'genies') are used as a plot device and one of the supernatural beings that the main characters come in contact with. Mentioned in 7 episodes, 2.20 "What is and What Should Never Be", 6.01 "Exile on Main St", 6.10 "Caged Heat", 7.22 "There Will Be Blood", 8.20 "Pac-Man Fever", 9.20 "Bloodlines", and 13.16 "Scoobynatural".

|iso3=sdn |glotto=gall1276 |glottorefname=Gallurese Sardinian |lingua=51-AAA-pd |map=Sardinia Language Map.png |mapcaption=Languages and dialects of Sardinia }} '''Gallurese''' (''gadduresu'') is an [[Italo-Dalmatian languages|Italo-Dalmatian]] [[Romance languages|Romance]] [[lect]] spoken in the region of [[Gallura]], in the northeastern part of [[Sardinia]]. It is often considered a [[dialect]] of southern [[Corsican language|Corsican]], or even a transitional language between [[Corsican language|Corsican]] and [[Sardinian language|Sardinian]]. Gallurese's morphology and vocabulary are close to those of [[Corsican language|Corsican]], in particular with the southern dialects of [[Sartene]] and [[Porto-Vecchio]], whereas its phonology and syntax are similar to those of Sardinian.[http://maxia-mail.doomby.com/medias/files/atti-convegno-palau-2014-def.pdf Atti Convegno Lingua Gallurese, Palau 2014] One third of Gallurese vocabulary is also influenced by [[Logudorese dialect|Logudorese]] Sardinian, [[Catalan language|Catalan]], and [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. The [[Sassarese language]], spoken in the area of [[Sassari]], shares similar transitional traits between [[Tuscan dialect|Tuscan]], Corsican and Sardinian. == Typical constitutional elements of Gallurese == [[Image:Dialetti corsi.png|thumb|left|Corsican dialects, including Gallurese.]] *the plural form of nouns in ''-i'' (''ghjanni'' or ''polti'' 'doors') are like in Corsican and Italian, and not as in ''-s'' like in Sardinian (''jannas'', ''portas''), French, Spanish, Catalan, etc. * Latin 'll' has become ''-dd-'' (like ''casteddu, coraddu'' 'castle', 'coral'), the same as in Sardinian, southern Corsican and Sicilian (but ''castellu, corallu'' in northern Corsican); *''-r-'' modified to ''-l-'' (''poltu'' 'port', while ''portu'' in Corsican and Sardinian); *''-chj-'' and ''-ghj-'' sounds (''ghjesgia'' 'church', ''occhji'' 'eyes'), like in Corsican, while Sardinian is ''cresia, ogros''. * articles ''lu'', ''la'', ''li'', like in ancient Corsican dialects (''u'', ''a'', ''i'' in modern Corsican, ''su'', ''sa'', ''sos'', ''sas'' in Sardinian); == Relation to Corsican == Gallurese is classified by some linguists as a dialect of Corsican,Blasco Ferrer 1984: 180–186, 200Contini 1987: 1°, 500–503Dettori 2002 and by others as a dialect of Sardinian.Loporcaro 2009: 159–167 In any case, a great deal of similarity exists between [[Corsican language|Southern Corsican dialects]] and Gallurese, while there is relatively more distance from the neighbouring [[Sardo logudorese|Sardinian varieties]]. |} == History == The most ancient literary sources in Gallurese date back to the early 17th century, mainly as poetry and religious odes. Some late Middle Age fragments suggest that the formation of the language could be dated to the early 15th century. The origin and the development of Gallurese are debated. [[Max Leopold Wagner]] and [[Maurice Le Lannou]] argued that successive migration waves from Southern [[Corsica]], promoted under the [[Kingdom of Aragon|Aragonese]] rule to repopulate an area devastated by famine and pandemics, were crucial in the formation of a slightly hybridized version of Corsican. == See also == * [[Sardinia]] * [[Corsican language]] * [[Sassarese]] * [[Sardinian language]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *Maxia, Mauro. |1996|2001|end=divorced}}}} | children = 3, including [[Jake Busey]] }} '''William Gary Busey''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|juː|s|i}}; born June 29, 1944){{cite web |url=http://www.familytreelegends.com/records/txbirths?c=search&first=William&last=Busey&spelling=Exact&11_year=&11_month=0&11_day=0&4=&14=&SubmitSearch.x=28&SubmitSearch.y=12 |title=Texas Births, 1926–1995 |publisher=familytreelegends.com |accessdate=December 19, 2010 }} is an American [[actor]]. A prolific [[character actor]], Busey has appeared in over 150 films, including ''[[Lethal Weapon]]'' (1987), ''[[Predator 2]]'' (1990), ''[[Point Break (1991 film)|Point Break]]'' (1991), ''[[Under Siege]]'' (1992), ''[[The Firm (1993 film)|The Firm]]'' (1993), ''[[Carried Away (1996 film)|Carried Away]]'' (1996), ''[[Black Sheep (1996 film)|Black Sheep]]'' (1996), ''[[Lost Highway (film)|Lost Highway]]'' (1997), ''[[Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (film)|Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas]]'' (1998), ''[[The Gingerdead Man]]'' (2005) and ''[[Piranha 3DD]]'' (2012). Busey also made guest appearances on television shows such as ''[[Gunsmoke]]'', ''[[Walker, Texas Ranger]]'', ''[[Law & Order]]'', ''[[Scrubs (TV series)|Scrubs]]'', and ''[[Entourage (U.S. TV series)|Entourage]]''. For portraying [[Buddy Holly]] in ''[[The Buddy Holly Story]]'' (1978), Busey was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]] and won the [[National Society of Film Critics Award for Best Actor]]. ==Early life== Busey was born in [[Goose Creek, Texas#History|Goose Creek]], [[Texas]], the son of Sadie Virginia (née Arnett), a [[homemaker]], and Delmer Lloyd Busey, a construction design manager.{{cite web |url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/14/Gary-Busey.html |title=Gary Busey Biography (1923)|website=Filmreference.com|accessdate=2017-08-18}} He graduated from [[Nathan Hale High School (Oklahoma)|Nathan Hale High School]] in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma|Tulsa]], [[Oklahoma]] in 1962. While attending [[Pittsburg State University]] in [[Pittsburg, Kansas|Pittsburg]], [[Kansas]] on a football scholarship, he became interested in acting.{{cite web|url = http://www.ebiog.com/biography/2184/gary-busey/bio.htm|title = Gary Busey|accessdate = August 5, 2007|work = eBiog|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071008120031/http://www.ebiog.com/biography/2184/gary-busey/bio.htm|archivedate = October 8, 2007|df = mdy-all}} He then transferred to [[Oklahoma State University - Stillwater|Oklahoma State University]] in [[Stillwater, Oklahoma|Stillwater]], Oklahoma where he quit school just one class short of graduation. ==Career== ===Early career=== [[File:Texas Wheelers cast.JPG|thumb|right|Gary Busey (standing), [[Mark Hamill]] and [[Jack Elam]] from ''[[The Texas Wheelers]]'', 1974]] Busey began his show business career as a drummer in The Rubber Band.Johnny Carson Show August 23, 1985 He appears on several [[Leon Russell]] recordings, credited as playing drums under the names "Teddy Jack Eddy"[http://tulsatvmemories.com/mazeppa2.html Tulsa TV Memories.com], Gary Busey reference as Teddy Jack Eddy in Tulsa, OK. and "Sprunk",{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} a character he created when he was a cast member of a local television comedy show in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], called ''The Uncanny Film Festival and Camp Meeting'' on station [[KTUL]] (which starred fellow Tulsan [[Gailard Sartain]] as "Dr. Mazeppa Pompazoidi"). For his skits on Uncanny Film Festival, Busey drew on his American Hero, belligerent, know-it-all character. When he told [[Gailard Sartain]] his character needed a name, Sartain replied, "Take three: Teddy, Jack and Eddy." He played in a band called Carp, which released one album on [[Epic Records]] in 1969.[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p16310|pure_url=yes}} Carp] at [[AllMusic]] Busey continued to play several small roles in both film and television during the 1970s. In 1975, as the character "Harvey Daley," he was the last person killed on the series ''[[Gunsmoke]]'' (in the third-to-last episode, No. 633 – "The Busters").https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0594408/ ===Rise to prominence=== [[File:Gary Busey (1976).jpg|thumb|right|200px|Gary Busey at the premiere of ''[[A Star Is Born (1976 film)|A Star Is Born]]'' in 1976]] In 1974, Busey made his major film debut with a supporting role in [[Michael Cimino]]'s buddy action caper ''[[Thunderbolt and Lightfoot]]'', starring [[Clint Eastwood]] and [[Jeff Bridges]]. In 1976, he was hired by [[Barbra Streisand]] and her producer-boyfriend [[Jon Peters]] to play Bobby Ritchie, road manager to [[Kris Kristofferson]]'s character in the remake film ''[[A Star Is Born (1976 film)|A Star is Born]]''. On the DVD commentary of the film, Streisand says Busey was great and that she had seen him on a TV series and thought he had the right qualities to play the role. In 1978, he starred as rock legend [[Buddy Holly]] in ''[[The Buddy Holly Story]]'' with Sartain as [[The Big Bopper]]. For his performance, Busey received the greatest critical acclaim of his career and the movie earned Busey an [[Academy Award]] nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] and the [[National Society of Film Critics]]' [[National Society of Film Critics Award for Best Actor|Best Actor award]]. In the same year he also starred in the small yet acclaimed drama ''[[Straight Time]]'' and the surfing movie ''[[Big Wednesday]]'', which is now a minor cult classic. In the 1980s, Busey's roles included the critically acclaimed western ''[[Barbarosa]]'', the comedies ''[[D.C. Cab]]''''[[People (American magazine)|People]]'' May 15, 1989, pp. 65–68 and ''[[Insignificance (film)|Insignificance]]'', and the [[Stephen King]] adaptation ''[[Silver Bullet (film)|Silver Bullet]]''. He played one of the primary antagonists opposite [[Mel Gibson]] and [[Danny Glover]] in the action comedy ''[[Lethal Weapon]]''. In the 1990s, he had prominent supporting roles in successful action films such as ''[[Predator 2]]'', ''[[Point Break (1991 film)|Point Break]]'' and ''[[Under Siege]]''. He also appeared in ''[[Rookie of the Year (film)|Rookie of the Year]]'', ''[[The Firm (1993 film)|The Firm]]'', ''[[Black Sheep (1996 film)|Black Sheep]]'', ''[[Lost Highway (film)|Lost Highway]]'', and ''[[Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (film)|Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas]]''. Busey sang the song "Stay All Night" on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' in March 1979 (season 4, episode 14), and on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' in the 1990s.{{youtube|hwNSXNXA3nU|Gary Busey - Stay All Night}} ===2000s–present=== In 2003, Busey starred in a Comedy Central reality show, ''[[I'm with Busey]]''. In 2005, he also voiced himself in an episode of ''[[The Simpsons]]''{{cite episode | title = On a Clear Day I Can't See My Sister | episodelink = On a Clear Day I Can't See My Sister | series = The Simpsons | serieslink = The Simpsons | network = Fox | airdate = 2005-06-03 | season = 16 | number = 11 }} and appeared in the popular miniseries ''[[Into the West (miniseries)|Into the West]]''. Busey controversially appeared in the 2006 Turkish nationalist film ''[[Valley of the Wolves: Iraq]],'' (Kurtlar Vadisi: Irak, in [[Turkish language|Turkish]]), which was accused of fascism, [[anti-Americanism]]{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4700154.stm |work=BBC News | title=Turkish rush to embrace anti-US film | date=February 10, 2006 | accessdate=May 3, 2010}} and [[anti-Semitism]].{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/0,1518,402432,00.html |title=Turkish Film Uproar: Attacking the American Enemy on Screen – International – Spiegel Online – News |work=Der Spiegel |date=February 22, 2006 |accessdate=January 7, 2012}} In 2007, he appeared as himself in a prominent recurring role on [[HBO]]'s ''[[Entourage (U.S. TV series)|Entourage]]'', in which he parodied his eccentric image, ultimately appearing on three episodes of the show. In 2008, he joined the second season of the reality show ''[[Celebrity Rehab with Dr. Drew]]''.Archive of {{cite web |url=http://blog.vh1.com/2008-06-10/new-slate-of-celebs-check-into-rehab-2-with-dr-drew/ |title="Celebs Check Into Rehab 2 With Dr. Drew" |accessdate=2010-03-22 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080613005309/http://blog.vh1.com/2008-06-10/new-slate-of-celebs-check-into-rehab-2-with-dr-drew/ |archivedate=June 13, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}, [[VH!]] [[press release]], June 10, 2008 Busey returned to reality television in ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. season 11)|Celebrity Apprentice 4]]'', which premiered in March 2011,{{cite web |url=http://tvdonewright.com/2010/11/celebrity-apprentice-season-four-cast-revealed/ |title=Celebrity Apprentice Season Four Cast Revealed |last=Wright |first=Adam |date=November 18, 2010 |publisher=TVDoneWright.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129202802/http://tvdonewright.com/2010/11/celebrity-apprentice-season-four-cast-revealed/ |archivedate=November 29, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} and appeared again in ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. season 13)|Celebrity Apprentice 6]]''. There, he briefly reprised his role as Buddy Holly by performing "Not Fade Away". In a series of 2010 YouTube advertisements for [[Vitamin Water]], Busey appeared as Norman Tugwater, a lawyer who defends professional athletes' entitlements to a cut from [[Fantasy football (American)|Fantasy Football]] team owners.{{cite web |url=http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/lawyer_norman_tugwater_ready_to_sue_for_pro_athletes_fantasy_rights/ |title=‘Lawyer Norman Tugwater’ Ready to Sue for Pro Athletes’ Fantasy Rights |date=August 30, 2010 |last=Cassens Weiss |first=Debra |work=[[ABA Journal]] |publisher=[[American Bar Association]]}} In 2014, he became a celebrity spokesperson for [[Amazon Fire TV]]. That August, he appeared in, and became the first American winner of the fourteenth series of the UK version of ''[[Celebrity Big Brother 14|Celebrity Big Brother]]''. On September 1, 2015, it was announced that he would be competing on the [[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. season 21)|21st season]] of ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]''. He was paired with professional dancer [[Anna Trebunskaya]].{{cite web|url=http://abc.go.com/shows/dancing-with-the-stars/cast-announcement|title=Dancing with the Stars Season 21 Cast Announcement|work=ABC|date=September 2, 2015|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} Busey and Trebunskaya made it to Week 4 of competition but were then eliminated and finished in 10th place.{{cite web|url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/dancing-with-the-stars/dancing-with-the-stars-recap-m-57650.aspx|title='Dancing with the Stars' Recap: Most Memorable Years for the Top 10|work=buddytv.com|accessdate=October 5, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170824180449/http://www.buddytv.com/articles/dancing-with-the-stars/dancing-with-the-stars-recap-m-57650.aspx|archive-date=August 24, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ==Personal life== [[File:Gary Busey 2007.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.6|Busey in September 2007]] In 1971, Busey's wife Judy Helkenberg gave birth to their son, [[Jake Busey|William Jacob "Jake" Busey]]. Busey and Helkenberg divorced when Jake was 19 years old. Busey has a daughter named Alectra from a previous relationship.{{cite web|title=First Photos: Gary Busey Introduces Son Luke|author=James Peragine|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2010/05/06/first-photos-gary-busey-introduces-son-luke|accessdate=August 15, 2017}} On December 4, 1988, Busey was severely injured in a motorcycle accident in which he was not wearing a [[helmet]]. His skull was fractured, and doctors feared he suffered permanent brain damage.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/health/spotlight/2001-07-05-busey-brain-injury.htm|title=Gary Busey ministers to brain injury community|accessdate=August 5, 2007|last=Moran|first=W. Reed|date=July 5, 2001|work=USA Today}} In 1996, Busey publicly announced that he was a [[Christianity|Christian]], saying: "I am proud to tell Hollywood I am a Christian. For the first time I am now free to be myself."{{cite web|last=Cramberg|first=Joanne|title=Tulsa's 'Bad Boy' Gary Busey Accepts Jesus|url=http://www.connectionmagazine.org/archives_old/largeset/badboy.htm|accessdate=April 29, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Virtue|first=David|title=Rescued From The Present Evil Age|url=http://listserv.virtueonline.org/pipermail/virtueonline_listserv.virtueonline.org/2000-September/001610.html|accessdate=April 29, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304133832/http://listserv.virtueonline.org/pipermail/virtueonline_listserv.virtueonline.org/2000-September/001610.html|archive-date=March 4, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Busey cites the motorcycle accident, as well as a 1995 cocaine overdose,{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/01/06/gary-busey-cocaine-motorc_n_4538289.html|title=Gary Busey On His Life-Changing Cocaine Overdose And Motorcycle Accident (VIDEO)|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]/[[Oprah Winfrey Network (U.S. TV channel)|Oprah Winfrey Network]]|date=January 21, 2014|accessdate=July 24, 2016}} as events that strengthened his religious faith. In 1997, Busey underwent successful surgery to remove a cancerous, plum-sized tumor from his sinus cavity. The growth was found after Busey began suffering nose bleeds.{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/34581/gary-busey-heads-for-cancer-surgery|title=Gary Busey Heads for Cancer Surgery|publisher=}} During the filming of the second season of ''[[Celebrity Rehab with Dr. Drew#Season 2|Celebrity Rehab]]'' in 2008, Busey was referred to psychiatrist Dr. [[Charles Sophy]]. Sophy suspected that Busey's brain injury has had a greater effect on him than realized. He described it as essentially weakening his mental "filters" and causing him to speak and act impulsively. Sophy recommended Busey take [[valproic acid]] (Depakote), with which Busey agreed.{{cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/shows/dyn/Celebrity_rehab_2_with_dr_drew/144584/episode_about.jhtml|title=Celebrity Rehab 2 with Dr. Drew (Episode 2)|accessdate=March 26, 2009}} In February 2010, Busey's fiancée Steffanie Sampson gave birth to their son, Luke Sampson Busey.{{cite news|author=Kate {{Other uses2|Gry}}
The '''-gry puzzle''' is a popular [[word puzzle]] that asks for the third English word that ends with the letters ''-gry'' other than ''angry'' and ''hungry''. Specific wording varies substantially, but the puzzle has no clear answer, as there are no other common English words that end in ''-gry''.<ref>(Uncommon such words include aggry and puggry.) Both ''[[Webster's Third New International Dictionary]] of the English Language, Unabridged'' (Merriam-Webster, Inc., 2002, {{ISBN|0-87779-201-1}}) and the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]], Second Edition'' (Oxford University Press, 1989, {{ISBN|0-19-861186-2}}) contain the compound word "aggry bead." To find a third word ending in -gry that is not part of a phrase, you must turn to archaic, obsolete, or uncommon words, or personal or place names.</ref><ref>[[Collins English Dictionary]] contains aggry as a standalone word. The only -gry words playable in Scrabble are aggry, ahungry, angry, hungry and puggry.</ref>  Interpretations of the puzzle suggest it is either an answerless hoax; a trick question; a sincere question asking for an obscure word; or a corruption of more straightforward puzzle, which may have asked for words containing ''-gry'' (such as ''[[griffin|gryphon]]''). Of these, countless trick question variants and obscure English words (or nonce words) have been proposed. The lack of a conclusive answer has ensured the enduring popularity of the puzzle, and it has become one of the most frequently asked word puzzles.<ref name="cole">{{cite book |last= Cole |first= Chris |title= Wordplay, A Curious Dictionary of Language Oddities |publisher= Sterling Publishing Co., Inc. |year= 1999 |pages= 96–100 |isbn= 0-8069-1797-0 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last= Daly |first= Matthew |title= Usenet rec.puzzles Frequently Asked Questions |work= "nugry (noo-gree or nyu-gree) n. 1. A newcomer who fails to follow established rules or procedures. 2. One who shows his inexperience by acting inappropriately. 3. One who posts the -GRY puzzle to rec.puzzles, in violation of the FAQ." |url= http://www.mathematik.uni-bielefeld.de/~sillke/PUZZLES/rec-puzzles-faq |accessdate= 2007-04-22 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070326044816/http://www.mathematik.uni-bielefeld.de/~sillke/PUZZLES/rec-puzzles-faq| archivedate= 26 March 2007<!--Added by DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= Fundis |first= Lois |title= STUMPER-L Reference Librarian Listserver archives October 1999 (#1042) |work= "Gry is a fightin' word to some of us by now; others will take your question as a reminder to change the oil in their cars (every three months)." }}</ref>

The ultimate origin and original form of the puzzle is unknown, but it was popularized in 1975, starting in the New York area, and has remained popular into the 21st century. Various [[#Similar puzzles|similar puzzles]] exist, though these have straightforward answers. The most notable is "words ending in ''-dous''", which has been popular since the 1880s.

==Answers==
Various proposed answers exist, stating that the question is one of the following:
* A hoax – there is no answer, and its purpose (or effect) is to frustrate.<ref name="safire1980">{{cite journal |authorlink=William Safire |first=William |last=Safire |title=On Language: Ending with "gry" |journal=The New York Times Magazine |date=27 July 1980 |pages=8–10}}, reprinted in {{cite book |title=What's the Good Word? |authorlink=William Safire |first=William |last=Safire |year=1982 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?ei=GCIzVe2bG4OXgwSo8oDIAQ&id=dOT8okA-dCQC&dq=gry+safire&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=gry p. 63–64], 'ending with "gry"'}}</ref>
* A trick question, with various answers depending on precise wording.
* A sincere question asking for an obscure word, most often proposed as {{linktext|aggry}}, {{linktext|meagry}}, or {{linktext|puggry}}
* A corruption of a more straightforward word puzzle, namely a word containing the sequence "gry", though not necessarily at the (tail) end, in which case the answer is {{linktext|gryphon}} which is uncommon but in use.<ref name="usenix1983"/><ref>[http://www.facstaff.bucknell.edu/rbeard/gry.html The Third English Word Ending on "gry"], quotes a Rush Elkins who heard it in 1969 or 1970 at the University of Florida, in which case appearing anywhere in the word was ok, and later realized that it was ''gryphon''.</ref><ref>rec.puzzles, [https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/rec.puzzles/a7tX-zTO_yw gry words], October 1, 1995</ref>

This topic is a source of lively interest, both to lovers of word puzzles and lovers of words. Intriguingly, there are members of the latter group who have little or no interest in the puzzle, per se; the challenge is in the list (of words). For both groups, much of the appeal lies in the [[quest]], either to trace the origin of the puzzle or compile a complete list of words ending in -gry.

More recently, the word ''hangry''—a [[portmanteau]] of 'hungry' and 'angry'—has been used to refer to an irritable state induced by lack of food.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Salis|first1=Amanda|title=The science of 'hangry:' Why some people get grumpy when they're hungry|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/20/health/science-behind-being-hangry/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=27 May 2016|date=July 20, 2015}}</ref>  Oxford Dictionaries (controlled by, but more lax than, the [[Oxford English Dictionary]]) added ''hangry'' on 27 August 2015,<ref>http://blog.oxforddictionaries.com/press-releases/oxforddictionaries-com-quarterly-update-new-words-added-today-include-hangry-grexit-and-wine-oclock/</ref><ref>http://time.com/4010748/oxford-dictionary-update-2015/</ref><ref>http://www.chicagotribune.com/dining/hangry-wine-o-clock-new-food-words-oxford-dictionary-story.html</ref> and the full Oxford English Dictionary added ''hangry'' in 2018.<ref>https://public.oed.com/blog/january-2018-update-new-words-notes/</ref>

==History==
There are anecdotal reports of various forms of the puzzle dating to the 1950s or earlier; the ultimate origin is presumably an oral tradition or a lost book of puzzles.<ref>
"[http://www.worldwidewords.org/articles/gry.htm I Spy Gry!]", ''World Wide Words,'' [[Michael Quinion]], page created 26 Oct. 1996, sast updated: 19 May 2001</ref> However, the first documented evidence is from early 1975 in the [[New York metropolitan area]], and the puzzle rapidly gained popularity in this year. The most likely source is the talk show of [[Bob Grant (radio host)|Bob Grant]], from some program in early or mid March 1975.

[[Merriam-Webster]], publishers of the leading American dictionaries, first heard of this puzzle in a letter dated March 17, 1975, from Patricia Lasker of [[Brooklyn, New York]]. Lasker says her plant manager heard the question on an unnamed [[quiz show]]. Since that time Merriam-Webster has received about four letters each year<ref name="cole"/> asking the question.

The puzzle first appears in print in Anita Richterman's "Problem Line" column in ''[[Newsday]]'' on April 29, 1975. One "M.Z." from [[Wantagh, New York]] states that the problem was asked on a TV quiz program. Richterman states that she asked a learned professor of English for help when she first received the inquiry, and he did not respond for over a month. This agrees with the Merriam-Webster report, suggesting a quiz show in early or mid March 1975.

In Anita Richterman's column on May 9, 1975, several correspondents reported that they had heard the puzzle on the [[Bob Grant (radio host)|Bob Grant]] radio talk show on [[WMCA (AM)|WMCA]] in New York City. This suggests either that the earlier claims of a (TV) quiz show confused a talk show with a quiz show, or that there was another unspecified quiz show that was then repeated by Grant.<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Origin of the -Gry Problem |author=Chris Cole |url=http://digitalcommons.butler.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=4538&context=wordways |journal=Word Ways |volume=34 |issue=1 |year=2012 }}</ref> The majority of readers gave the answer "[[wikt:gry|gry]]," an obsolete unit of measure invented by [[John Locke]]. It is unclear whether this was the answer given on the Grant show, or what the precise wording had been.

By fall 1975 the puzzle had reached the Delaware Valley, again apparently by radio, by which time the puzzle seems to have mutated to a form in which the missing word is an adjective that describes the state of the world.{{sfn|Beaman|1976|loc="A Philadelphia Story", pp. 43–44}}

The puzzle has had occasional bouts of popularity: after its initial popularity in 1975, it was popular in 1978, then again in 1995–1996.<ref>''[[Stumpers-L]]'', Good Gry-f!  How many words end in -gry?, by Glenn Kersten, December 1999: "Fortunately, the popularity of the -gry puzzle has lessened since the boom era of 1995-1996, but SLS Reference Service still receives the question from time to time. Since the same question was a fad in 1978 (see our articles in the November and December 1978 issues of Points of Reference), it looks as though reference librarians should prepare for a 17-year cycle. Hmmm, remind you of anything? The next plague should hit reference desks in the year 2012."</ref>

===Reports of earlier versions===
The most credible report of an early version was given on [[Stumpers-L]],<ref name="stumpersl1999">''[[Stumpers-L]]'', Good Gry-f!  How many words end in -gry?, by Glenn Kersten, December 1999</ref> which reported a trick question formulation from an eight-page pamphlet entitled ''Things to Think About'', probably dating to the 1940s:

{{quotation|One enterprising reference librarian found an eight-page pamphlet (no copyright date, but from the appearance probably printed in the 1940s) entitled Things to Think About. The booklet was filled with riddles, including the following:

There are three words in the English language that end with -gry. Two of these are angry and hungry. The third word is a very common word, and you use it often. If you have read what I have told you, you will see that I have given you the third word. What is the third word? Think very carefully.

Three! The question has nothing to do with angry, hungry, or any of the many other obscure words that end in -gry, it is a simple question asking you what the third word in the sentence is. As you take tests, remember this.}}

==Similar puzzles==
{{anchor|-dous}}
There are numerous similar puzzles, giving letter sequences that rarely occur in words.<ref name="lederer">''The Word Circus: A Letter-perfect Book,'' by Richard Lederer, Dave Morice, 1998, [https://books.google.com/books?id=wHlHFp9zG1wC&pg=PA259 p. 259]</ref> The most-notable of these is the ''-dous'' puzzle of finding words ending in ''-dous'', which was popular in the 1880s. This took various forms, sometimes simply listing all words or all common words,<ref name="nandq"/><ref>''The Brooklyn Magazine,'' Volumes II, Number 2, 1885, May, [https://books.google.com/books?id=9KbQAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA2-PA85&dq=dous+tremendous+stupendous+hazardous+horrendous+jeopardous p. 85]</ref> sometimes being posed as a riddle, giving the three common words, ''[[wikt:tremendous|tremendous]]'', ''[[wikt:stupendous|stupendous]]'', and ''[[wikt:hazardous|hazardous]]'', and requesting the rarer fourth, which is ''[[wikt:jeopardous|jeopardous]]''. This form originated in 1883, with an A.A. of Glasgow writing to [[George Augustus Henry Sala]] in his "Echoes of the Week" column in the ''[[Illustrated London News]].''<ref>Collected in ''Echoes of the year Eighteen Hundred and Eighty-Three,'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=x6YIAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA337&dq=dous+tremendous+stupendous p. 337]</ref><ref>See credit of Sala in ''Tidbits,'' 1884 February 2, [https://books.google.com/books?id=sj85AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA246&dq=dous+tremendous+stupendous p. 246]; reprint: [https://books.google.com/books?id=vPgIAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA327&dq=dous+hazardous+tremendous p. 327]</ref>
This question has had enduring popularity,<ref>''Graphite,'' 1909 March, "'Dous' Sequel", [https://books.google.com/books?id=sZzmAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA1976&dq=tremendous+stupendous+dous p. 1076]</ref> even inspiring a contest,<ref name="spatula">''The Spatula,'' Volume 2, 1895, [https://books.google.com/books?id=nxVOAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA360&dq=dous+tremendous+stupendous p. 360]</ref> though the words have proven less stable: today ''jeopardous'' is considered too rare, and the formerly unpopular ''[[wikt:horrendous|horrendous]]'' has taken its place; this change occurred as early as 1909.<ref name="eandp">Editor and Publisher, Volume 9, 1909, [https://books.google.com/books?id=7yVDAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA18-IA89&dq=tremendous+stupendous+hazardous+dous p. 89]</ref> At times other words such as ''[[wikt:hybridous|hybridous]]'' have been accepted.<ref name="spatula"/> Today ''[[wikt:hazardous|hazardous]]'' is typically the omitted word, and differs from the others in being a visible compound ''[[wikt:hazard|hazard]]'' + ''[[wikt:-ous|-ous]].'' This puzzle has continued in popularity through the end of the 20th century,<ref>''The Game of Words,'' Willard Epsy, 1971</ref>{{sfn|Beaman|1976|loc="Kickshaws: An Earlier Kickshaw", [https://books.google.com/books?id=9IgsAAAAMAAJ&q=tremendous+stupendous p. 40]}} with recent versions giving it as an alternative to the gry puzzle.<ref>''The Word Circus: A Letter-perfect Book,'' by Richard Lederer, Dave Morice, 1998, [https://books.google.com/books?id=wHlHFp9zG1wC&pg=PA229 p. 229]</ref>

Another similar one is words ending in ''-cion'', of which the common words are ''[[wikt:coercion|coercion]]'', ''[[wikt:scion|scion]]'', and ''[[wikt:suspicion|suspicion]]''.<ref name="nandq">''Notes and Queries,'' Vol. VI, No. 10, 1889, October, [https://books.google.com/books?id=0qYXAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA365&dq=cion p. 365]</ref><ref name="eandp"/>

The most similar to the gry puzzle in form is to find three words that contain the letter sequence ''shion'', to which the answer is ''[[wikt:cushion|cu'''shion''']]'', ''[[wikt:fashion|fa'''shion''']]'', and ''[[wikt:parishioner|pari'''shion'''er]]'';  this is typically stated by giving ''cushion'' and ''fashion'', and requesting the third word, namely ''parishioner''.<ref name="lederer"/><ref>''Weeds in the Garden of Words: Further Observations on the Tangled History of the English Language,'' Kate Burridge, 2005, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Iq9R_9AQ19gC&pg=PA82 p. 82], p. 184</ref> This can be modified to finding words ''ending'' with ''-shion'', in which case the answer is the obsolete word ''[[wikt:parishion|parishion]]'', which is a synonymous variant of ''parishioner''. This has not been nearly as popular as the gry puzzle.

==Solution techniques==
The standard way to solve such puzzles is to use a [[reverse dictionary]], or to perform an exhaustive search through a dictionary, either manually, which is tedious and error-prone, or using computer tools such as [[grep]], which requires an electronic word list. At the origin of the gry puzzle, the standard reverse dictionary in modern English was the "Air Force Reverse Dictionary" (formally the ''Normal and Reverse Word List'', compiled under the direction of A. F. Brown), which did not have additional answers for gry. The most plausible answer at the time was ''[[wikt:meagry|meagry]]'', found in the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]''.{{sfn|Beaman|1976|loc="A Philadelphia Story", pp. 43–44}} A more elaborate strategy is to list words that have endings similar to gry, such as ''-gary'', and then search a larger dictionary for obsolete variants ending in ''-gry'', for example ''begry'' for ''beggary''.{{sfn|Scheetz|1989|p=198–199}}

From around 1980 electronic word lists became widely available on [[Unix]] systems, and searching for answers to the gry puzzle was an occasional benchmark; this also turned up ''gryphon'' in some cases, if match is not required to be at the end.<ref name="usenix1983">USENIX Association, Software Tools User Group, Summer Conference Proceedings, Volume 2, 1983, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=5vsyVfOxHsGaNq7hgJgJ&id=47BQAAAAMAAJ&dq=gry p. 343]: One test was to find words containing the letter sequence "gry." The "grep gry /usr/dict/words" ran significantly faster on the Concept than on the VAX (the words found were angry, hungry, and gryphon).</ref> This is now easily done in milliseconds on modern personal computers:
<source lang="bash">
grep gry$ /usr/share/dict/words  # Search for words ending in gry
grep gry /usr/share/dict/words  # Search for words containing gry
</source>
